;;一名交易员经过纽约证券交易所大厅显示洲际交易所 (ICE) 交易信息的屏幕（纽约证券交易所）2016 年 3 月 1 日。路透社/Brendan McDermid;
;

;美国股指期货周四苦苦寻找方向，因为美联储何时开始放松金融状况的不确定性让投资者感到紧张。等待央行官员的进一步政策线索。

;

;劳动力市场疲软的迹象以及美联储在上次会议上强硬立场的缓和已将美国国债收益率从多年高点回落，帮助股市上扬。从 10 月份的低点开始强劲反弹。

;

;然而，由于本周几位美联储政策制定者反对市场对央行将很快开始降息的预期，涨势已经失去动力。

;< p>;基准标准普尔 500 指数 ;(.SPX); 周三小幅上涨，但成功延续了两年来最长的连续上涨势头。

;

;大多数交易员押注美联储今年将维持利率不变，5 月份至少降息 25 个基点的可能性为根据芝商所 (CME Group) 的 FedWatch 工具，这一数字接近 47%。

;

;“市场对于多久才会看到降息感到兴奋。 Equiti Capital 首席宏观经济学家斯图尔特·科尔 (Stuart Cole) 表示，“它传达了不太可能进一步加息的信息，因为降息即将到来。”

;

;“但事实并非如此，而且各个央行的评论也并非如此。” （央行）官员本周对此非常关注。”

;

;基准十年期国债收益率基本稳定在 4.5255%，而两年期国债收益率基本稳定在 4.5255%，这是最好的反映短期利率预期，小幅上涨至 4.9487%。

;

;芝加哥联储主席奥斯坦·古尔斯比 (Austan Goolsbee) 表示，美联储将需要密切关注长期债券收益率上升的影响，以确保据《华尔街日报》报道，未来一年经济放缓幅度不会超过预期。

;

;在美联储发言人中，主席杰罗姆·鲍威尔计划在国际货币基金组织 (IMF) 会议上发表讲话）东部时间下午 2 点（格林尼治标准时间 1900）举行的会议。他拒绝在周三的另一场会议上就货币政策发表评论。

;

;里士满联储行长托马斯·巴尔金 (Thomas Barkin) 预计也将在晚些时候讨论美国经济前景。

;

;投资者还将评估美国东部时间上午 8:30 发布的劳工部报告，该报告预计将显示截至 11 月 4 日当周的失业救济人数从上个月的 217,000 人增至 218,000 人。

;

;截至美国东部时间上午 7:03，道指 e-minis 上涨 38 点，即 0.11%，标准普尔 500 e-minis 上涨 3.25 点，即 0.07%，纳斯达克 100 e-minis 上涨下跌 15.25 点，即 0.1%。

;

;在盈利方面，;华特迪士尼; ;(DIS.N); 由于上海和香港主题公园的游客人数增加，这家娱乐公司的季度利润超出了华尔街的预期，盘前交易上涨 4.1%。

;

;;AMC Entertainment< /a>; ;(AMC.N); 因第三季度营收超出预期而上涨 2.7%估计。

;

;;米高梅国际酒店集团;;(MGM.N); 上涨 3.5%，超出第三季度预期赌场运营商受益于流行病限制的放松，利润和收入增加。

;;周四（11 月 9 日）加沙人向南部逃亡，寻求躲避以色列的空袭和激烈的地面战斗。;
;

;以色列军队在加沙地带北部的废墟建筑中与哈马斯武装分子作战周四，随着被围困的巴勒斯坦领土上平民的困境日益恶化，他们逐渐靠近两家大医院。

;

;在以色列告知后，数千名巴勒斯坦人正沿着一条危险的前线道路从陷入困境的北部逃往南部。居民们说，他们要撤离。

;

;但许多人仍留在北部，挤进希法医院和圣城医院，因为地面战斗在他们周围激烈进行，更多的以色列空袭从上空倾泻而下。< /p>;

;以色列表示，哈马斯的敌人在医院里设有指挥中心。

;

;在巴黎，来自约 80 个国家和组织的官员正在开会，协调对加沙的人道主义援助，并寻找帮助伤员的方法平民逃离了围困，现在已经进入第二个月了。

;

;援助机构呼吁立即;停火;。

;

;“我们不能再等了，”挪威难民秘书长扬·埃格兰说安理会称以色列的行为是“集体惩罚”。

;

;“如果不停火、解除围困、不分青红皂白的轰炸和战争，人类生命的流血事件将会继续。”

;

;他的呼吁是尽管以色列及其主要支持者美国拒绝全面停火，但联合国和国际红十字会对此表示赞同。

;

;以色列对加沙发动袭击，以回应哈马斯对以色列南部的跨境袭击据以色列统计，10 月 7 日，枪手杀害了 1,400 人，其中大部分是平民，并劫持了约 240 名人质。

;

;这是以色列 75 年历史上最严重的流血事件，引起了国际社会的谴责

;

;但是，随着一场人道主义灾难的展开，以色列在哈马斯统治飞地的报复行动引起了人们的高度关注。

;

;巴勒斯坦官员表示，10,569 名加沙居民遭受了苦难。截至周三，大约 40% 的人在空袭和炮击中丧生，其中约 40% 是儿童，而基本物资已经耗尽，以色列无情的轰炸使地区变成一片废墟。

;

;哈马斯据点加沙城的居民说以色列坦克驻扎在该地区周围。据报道，双方在激烈的巷战中互相造成严重伤亡。

;

;发誓要消灭哈马斯的以色列表示，在地面行动中，有 33 名士兵在挺进哈马斯的心脏地带时丧生。加沙城。

;

;以色列军方周三表示，经过与哈马斯和伊斯兰圣战武装分子在地面和地下进行了10个小时的战斗，以色列军队已经占领了加沙北部贾巴利亚的哈马斯军事据点17号。

;

;据称，部队杀死了数十名武装分子，缴获了武器，暴露了隧道竖井，并在谢赫拉德万社区的一栋住宅楼内发现了哈马斯武器制造基地。

;

;以色列军事镜头显示士兵穿过废墟，走进一座墙壁被炸毁的建筑物，找到了武器制造设备、指导手册和隧道竖井。

;

;附近是一间女孩的卧室，有粉红色的墙壁、粉红色的衣柜和三张小床。

;

;哈马斯武装派别表示，他们杀死的以色列士兵数量比军方公布的还要多，并摧毁了数十辆坦克、推土机和其他车辆。它发布了武装分子发射反坦克火箭并直接击中车辆的镜头。

;

;尽管以色列下令撤离其包围的地区，但仍有数千名巴勒斯坦人在加沙城内的 Al Shifa 医院寻求庇护。他们在医院场地的帐篷里避难，并表示他们无处可去。

;

;联合国人道主义办公室人道协调厅表示，以色列再次要求北部居民向南迁移，并开放了一个四小时的走廊，以防止北部地区的居民撤离。连续第五天。据称，周三约有 5 万人离开该地区。

;

;人道协调厅表示，主要道路周围的冲突和炮击仍在继续，危及撤离人员。尸体躺在路边，而大多数撤离者正在步行，因为以色列军方要求他们离开车辆。

;

;一名不愿透露姓名的居民说，他是带着自己的孩子过马路的。妻子和六个孩子，其中包括两个成年女儿，最初从靠近以色列边境的拜特哈农的家到加沙城避难。

;

;“没有出租车，只能乘坐少量出租车。你。你必须手里拿着你的身份证，在经过以色列坦克时举起它，然后再步行几公里寻找搭车的地方。”他说。

;

;来自以色列的大量流离失所者以色列前高级官员沙洛姆·本·哈南 (Shalom Ben Hanan) 表示，加沙 230 万人口已经挤满了南部的学校、医院和其他场所。

;

;在 Al Shifa 附近发生的战斗将对以色列军队构成挑战。辛贝特安全部门，因为部队可能需要疏散无视离开警告的平民。

;

;“他们（哈马斯）会向我们开枪，并会在医院里与我们并肩作战，”他在耶路撒冷告诉路透社。 “我们将为此付出高昂的代价。”

;

;虽然战斗集中在北部，但南部地区也经常受到攻击。

;

;在加沙主要南部地区汗尤尼斯周四早上，目击者称，周四早上，居民们在一座被以色列空袭摧毁的建筑物的废墟和扭曲的废墟中搜寻，希望找到幸存者。

;

;在巴黎举行的会议有阿拉伯国家、西方国家参加各国领导人、G20 成员国和无国界医生组织等非政府组织正在讨论减轻加沙苦难的措施，但对战斗的期望值很低。

;

;总统埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 在会议开幕时表示，呼吁人道主义暂停。

;

;他说：“情况很严重，而且每天都在恶化。”

;

;巴勒斯坦总理穆罕默德·什塔耶（Mohammad Shtayyeh），其巴勒斯坦权力机构在巴勒斯坦权力机构的自治有限。以色列占领的约旦河西岸，但 2007 年被哈马斯赶出加沙，出席了会议。以色列没有被邀请。

;

;“必须杀死多少巴勒斯坦人才能停止战争，”Shtayyeh 问道。 “在 30 天内杀死 10,000 人就足够了吗？”

;

;巴勒斯坦权力机构表示，加沙地带是其未来巴勒斯坦国设想的一个组成部分。以色列官员;表示; 他们不打算在战后占领加沙，但尚未阐明如何确保安全。以色列于 2005 年从加沙撤军。

;俄罗斯网络间谍幕后黑手于 2022 年末以一种罕见的高级形式破坏了乌克兰部分电网谷歌旗下的美国网络安全公司 Mandiant 表示，;周四的一份报告;。

;

;乌克兰主要情报机构 SBU 在给路透社的一份声明中证实，俄罗斯黑客袭击了该国与俄罗斯前线附近的一处设施。

;

;针对工业控制系统的成功黑客攻击相对独特，俄罗斯是少数有能力实施此类网络攻击的国家之一。

;

;“这次攻击代表了俄罗斯网络物理攻击能力的最新演变，报告称，自俄罗斯入侵乌克兰以来，这种攻击变得越来越明显。但该报告没有具体说明攻击所针对的具体设施。

;

;去年 10 月，发生了大规模的;俄罗斯导弹袭击乌克兰电网;导致该国许多地区停电，促使基辅停止电力出口，并使四个地区暂时断电。

;

;该黑客组织在网络安全研究界被称为“沙虫”，能够导致乌克兰一处不明区域停电。报告称，乌克兰在导弹袭击的同时触发了变电站的断路器。报告补充说，该组织随后部署了数据擦除恶意软件，以掩盖其踪迹。

;

;Sandworm 此前已被确定为俄罗斯 GRU 军事情报机构的网络战单位。

;

;俄罗斯外交部没有回应置评请求。无法联系到 GRU 置评。

;

;乌克兰外交部未发表评论。

;

;SBU 表示 Sandworm 是网络攻击的幕后黑手，该组织由 GRU 官员组成。该机构网络安全部门负责人 Illia Vitiuk 在一份声明中表示，此次攻击可能是为了最大限度地扩大俄罗斯导弹袭击的影响。

;

;沙虫黑客在 2015 年针对< a href="针对工业系统的成功黑客攻击相对独特，俄罗斯是少数有能力实施此类网络攻击的国家之一" target="_blank">;乌克兰电网;，导致断电约255,000 人。这次破坏性数字入侵被广泛认为是已知的首批针对电力网络的成功网络攻击之一。

;

;“类似的事件屈指可数，其中大多数是由 Sandworm 发起的，” Mandiant 分析师 Nathan Brubaker 表示。

;古巴人伊达尔贝托·埃查瓦里亚 (Idalberto Echavarria) 操纵轮椅上的妻子奥尔加 (Olga) 来到哈瓦那机场 2 号航站楼的排队队伍前面，避开了行李和一大群人向朋友和家人告别。

;

;拥挤的航站楼是古巴人乘飞机前往尼加拉瓜，然后陆路前往美国的出发点，也是古巴人疯狂旅行的晴雨表。对于许多人来说，比如埃查瓦里亚和他的妻子，这也成为古巴;经济危机;随着;看不到尽头;。

;

;“还有其他方法，但你需要钱或国外的家庭成员，”Echavarria 在一份路透社中告诉路透社在机场接受采访，提及;难民计划; 由美国总统乔·拜登政府于 1 月份提出，需要有美国境内的担保人。

;

;他和他的妻子因腿部感染而无法行走，没有退休金，也没有他说，他们的亲戚在国外地位很高，而且很难获得合法入境计划。

;

;“对我们来说，这是唯一的选择，也是最困难的，”埃查瓦里亚说。这对夫妇计划驾车穿越中美洲约 1,500 英里（2,400 公里）。

;

;美国是古巴移民的首选目的地，自 2022 年以来增加了古巴人的合法移民途径，包括;签证访问;哈瓦那，旨在减少非法移民。

;

;但本周在哈瓦那大使馆、市政公证人和机场对潜在移民的十几次采访表明，像埃查瓦里亚这样的许多人要么缺乏手段申请岛上为古巴人提供的签证计划，或者已经失去耐心等待轮到他们了。

;

;美国必须改变衡量人民福祉的方式，包括衡量他们认为自己在政治结果中拥有多少发言权，作为更大范围的一部分努力扭转整个经济领域日益加剧的不平等。

;

;这是对 ;新报告;。它包括的建议包括重新设计社会计划，旨在为那些面临经济困难的人提供更大的稳定性，以及向第二次世界大战的黑人退伍军人及其后代提供几十年前根据《退伍军人权利法案》而被剥夺的福利。

;

; There is growing concern about a contradiction in the US economy: jobs are plentiful and economic growth is strong, especially compared with other advanced economies, but surveys show many Americans are sour about the outlook.

;

;"We're close to full employment by traditional measures," said Matthew Slaughter, a member of the commission that wrote the report and the dean of Dartmouth College's Tuck School of Business. "But a lot of American families in surveys say they don't think it's going that well."

;

;Recent data underscores the problem. A report on consumer finances from the ;Federal Reserve; last month found that American families on average saw large gains in income and wealth from 2019 to 2022, but the income gains were largest among the highest-earning families, and fastest among white families. New estimates from the ;US Census Bureau; also show the share of income going to the top 5% grew from 2019 to 2022, extending a trend dating from the 1980s.

;

;Dissatisfaction with the status quo shows up in how Americans vote, said Nicholas Lemann, a co-chair of the commission and a professor at the Columbia Journalism School, noting there's now a competition between the two major political parties to be the "party of the working class." ;

;"There's a view that the good stuff in America gets concentrated on the coasts," Lemann added.

;

;This is the first time the AAAS, which was founded in 1780 to advance research and civil dialogue, has tackled a broad analysis of the US economy.

;Based in part on 31 "listening sessions" conducted with groups of working Americans, the commission developed a list of 15 recommendations on how to make the economy more equitable. ;

;A key part of the report is a ;new tool developed to measure the well-being of Americans;, which combines 11 different measures. Among the categories are indicators of health, such as life expectancy and the percentage of people with health insurance, and economic security, including the percentage of households that spend less than 30% of total income on housing.

;

;Researchers around the world have long sought to find better ways to gauge the well-being of people that look beyond measures such as economic growth or unemployment. One example is the Social Vulnerability Index, which uses Census data for every census tract to assess 14 social factors.

;

;The AAAS measure shows some broad trends that are well-known, such as pockets of poverty in the US South and affluent clusters along the coasts.

;

;One unique part of the measure is an attempt to quantify the "political voice" of Americans. A high level of support for an issue and a "yes" vote by their representative yielded a high score.

;

;The Venezuelan government will be in a strong position to increase social spending to woo voters in 2024 as relief from some US sanctions allows more oil income to flow into government coffers, analysts say.

;

;The United States in October temporarily rolled back some oil industry sanctions and lifted a ban on bond trading sanctions in exchange for an electoral deal between the government of President Nicolas Maduro and Venezuela's opposition.

;

;;Washington has conditioned; an extension of the relief on the release of political prisoners and what it says are "wrongfully detained" Americans, as well as the lifting of public office bans on people including the winner of the opposition's ;primary; nominating contest.

;

;The relaxed sanctions could lead to $1.4 billion in additional income for Venezuela over the next six months, analyst firm Sintesis Financiera said in a report.

;

;The additional oil income is expected to ;arrive gradually;, partly though the redirection of exports. One oil industry source told Reuters they expect export income to grow by 40% per month.

;

;Under the previous sanctions, state-run oil company PDVSA had to sell to Asian markets via intermediaries, a strategy that cut into government profits.

;

;"The increase in income will be gradual," said Jose Vielma, a ruling party lawmaker and member of the finance committee for the government-allied national assembly. "The contribution will go to social spending and services."

;

;The communications ministry and ruling party PSUV did not respond to requests for further comment on spending plans.

;

;The increased income will almost certainly lead to greater financial laxity "given the need to improve popular support for the government ahead of elections in the second half of 2024," said Sintesis Financiera.

;

;The government has traditionally increased social spending, public sector salaries, food distribution and housing construction projects ahead of elections, though national income has been limited over the last five years because of the sanctions and problems at PDVSA.

;

;If the sanctions relaxations continue next year and oil production goes up, the additional income could reach $7 billion in 2024, consulting firm Ecoanalitica said.

;

;"In electoral periods clientelist spending increases, and it's possible we'll see workers getting bonuses or improvements in the distribution of food," said Venezuelan political consultant and analyst Oswaldo Ramirez.

;

;"The challenge for the government is to convert that into votes... The ruling party has lost votes in part because of delays in salary increases and pensions," he said.

;

;The government has already this year launched new social programs - which it calls "missions" - for young people and women, the first since 2017.

;

;Such social programs distribute food, houses and even goods like motorcycle parts, cellphones and computer tablets.

;

;Opposition figures have criticized the missions for more than a decade, saying they are a poor response to the destruction of Venezuela's economy by the ruling party, amount to "extortion by hunger," and that public funds could be better employed raising public sector salaries and pensions.

;

;Economist Jose Guerra, a former opposition lawmaker and head of the non-governmental Venezuelan Finance Observatory, said public sector raises may still be too costly a prospect.

;

;"The government will spend but not at the levels it did before," he said.

;

;More income may also allow Maduro to revisit orthodox but insufficient ;inflation-fighting policies; that have led to lower spending and ;less availability of credit;, even as annual inflation reaches more than 300%.

;

;Public spending has fallen to 15% of gross domestic product from 40% a decade ago, according to economic analysts. That has led teachers, nurses and other public workers ;to march; for higher salaries as their wages ;shrink;.

;

;Some 2 million public workers earn between $45 and $60 per month, while private sector salaries are often more than $200, according to the Venezuelan Finance Observatory.

;

;The central bank should mint fewer bolivares if there is higher oil income, several analysts said, estimating prices could fall in what remains of the year and take inflation down to 250% year-on-year.

;Alphabet's ;(GOOGL.O); Google, Meta Platforms ;(META.O); and TikTok on Thursday won backing from Europe's top court in their fight against an Austrian law requiring them to delete hate speech or face fines of up to ($10.69 million).

;

;The Austrian law, enacted in 2021 and which obliges Big Tech to publish regular reports of illegal content, comes amid mounting concerns worldwide about hateful posts.

;The European Union recently adopted new rules called the ;Digital Services Act; (DSA) which require large online platforms to do more to tackle illegal and harmful online content or risk fines up to 6% of their annual turnover.

;

;Google, Meta and TikTok challenged the Austrian law in an Austrian court, saying that it is contrary to an EU rule which says online service providers are only subject to the rules of the country where they are established, while countries where they provide a service must refrain from applying their laws.

;

;The three companies, which have their European headquarters in Ireland, say they should only be subject to Irish rules. The Austrian court subsequently sought advice from the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), which sided with the companies.

;

;"A member state may not subject a communication platform provider established in another member state to general and abstract obligation," judges said.

;

;"Such a national approach is contrary to EU law, which ensures the free movement of information society services through the principle of control in the Member State of origin of the service concerned," they said.

;

;Google welcomed the ruling.

;

;"We are pleased with today's decision which reaffirms the importance of the EU's country of origin principle. We will study the judgment and continue to invest in the trust and safety of our users across our platforms," a Google spokesperson said.

;

;Meta and TikTok did not immediately respond to emails requesting comment.

;

;Thursday's ruling cannot be appealed.

;

;Argentina could see a resetting of some global ties depending on the result of its run-off presidential election later this month - although the value of trade with partners like China and Brazil may outweigh any short-term political posturing.

;

;While Economy Minister Sergio Massa, a pragmatist in the ruling left-leaning coalition, has signaled policy continuity, radical libertarian candidate Javier Milei has sharply lambasted China, Brazil, the pope, South America's Mercosur trade bloc and the China-led BRICS group.

;

;Massa and Milei will compete in a Nov. 19 head-to-head that looks likely to be a tight race, with angry voters ;deeply divided; amid inflation running at nearly 140%, two-fifths of the population in poverty, sky-high interest rates and capital controls hurting the economy.

;

;The vote could impact the global positioning of Argentina, South America's No. 2 economy, which is a major grains exporter as well as a lithium and shale producer. But years of volatility have made some international investors wary and it is the top debtor to the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

;

;Gustavo Martinez Pandiani, current Argentine ambassador to Switzerland and Massa's likely foreign minister, said a future Massa government would seek to improve the country's global partnerships.

;

;"While some promise to cut ties with Brazil or China, we want more markets and more trading partners, not less," he said.

;

;Milei has said he "won't make deals with communists" in China or Brazil, though he does back private trade. He has described climate change as a "lie of socialism" and said Argentine Pope Francis is "on the side of bloody dictatorships."

;

;Diana Mondino, Milei's likely foreign minister, said some of his statements had been blown out of context, and that in fact he would look "to reinsert Argentina into the world."

;

;"Not only is there not a problem with Brazil, but we hope to be able to trade as much as possible with Brazil," said Mondino, adding that with China - a key trade partner, creditor and investor - Milei would simply stop opaque state-to-state deals.

;

;That could include the country's $18 billion currency swap line with China, which has helped cash-strapped Argentina pay back its IMF debt. China is also a big investor in local lithium projects, hydro and nuclear.

;

;"What we are not going to do are secret contracts. Argentina, this government, in the last 20 years, has had multiple secret negotiations," she said. "That is not normal and it is what we have said we are not going to do."

;

;A current senior Foreign Ministry source, from the same Peronist coalition as Massa, predicted that Argentina's ties with Brazil and China would continue regardless of who won the election.

;

;"Relations with China are going to go as they have until now with either of the two candidates. The intense trade that exists with them cannot be dissolved," the person said, asking not to be identified.

;

;"The same thing would happen with Brazil: bad personal relations do not affect trade."

;

;TRADE BLOCS: MERCOSUR AND BRICS

;

;Massa and Milei have also clashed on ;Mercosur;, the regional trade bloc led by Argentina and Brazil that has faced internal tension from other members who say it is not an effective trade mechanism for negotiating global deals.

;

;The Peronists want to strengthen the bloc, while Milei has threatened to pull Argentina out of it.

;

;Pandiani said member countries needed to "modernize Mercosur to make it more efficient," and added that a Massa government would consider it their "main platform" for global trade.

;

;"Argentina has a very promising future, because it has what the world demands: proteins; traditional, green and transition energy; critical minerals such as lithium and copper; rare earths and qualified human resources," he said.

;

;The current government has also pushed to have Argentina in the China-backed BRICS group of developing countries, which also includes India, Brazil, Russia and South Africa. Argentina was ;invited to join the group; in August. Milei opposes joining.

;

;"The BRICS are not a trading bloc. As of now it's not clear why we would want to have membership in this group," said Mondino. The BRICS are a relatively loosely-formed group with diverse political and geographical positions.

;

;Pandiani disagreed. "Rejecting entry into BRICS is nonsense; we believe that Argentina should always sit at the negotiating tables where important issues for our future are discussed," he said.
